review.title: Learning Rich Geographical Representations: Predicting Colorectal Cancer Survival in the State of Iowa
review.abstract: Neural networks are capable of learning rich, nonlinear feature representations shown to be beneficial in many predictive tasks. In this work, we use these models to explore the use of geographical features in predicting colorectal cancer survival curves for patients in the state of Iowa, spanning the years 1989 to 2012. Specifically, we compare model performance using a newly defined metric -- area between the curves (ABC) -- to assess (a) whether survival curves can be reasonably predicted for colorectal cancer patients in the state of Iowa, (b) whether geographical features improve predictive performance, and (c) whether a simple binary representation or richer, spectral clustering-based representation perform better. Our findings suggest that survival curves can be reasonably estimated on average, with predictive performance deviating at the five-year survival mark. We also find that geographical features improve predictive performance, and that the best performance is obtained using richer, spectral analysis-elicited features.

metadata.title: Learning Rich Geographical Representations: Predicting Colorectal Cancer Survival in the State of Iowa

sections.text: I. INTRODUCTIONThe rise of machine learning and the accompanying development of various deep learning methods in recent years seems promising, as such methods are capable of learning rich, nonlinear characterizations, and such representations have proven useful in a variety of areas, including medicine and public health. This work looks at methods applied to such areas. Specifically, our focus is on exploring different representations of geographic characteristics that can be used to generate survival curves for patients in the State of Iowa. To investigate such a problem, we look at Figure 1, which shows that colorectal cancer mortality rates, which range from 1989 to 2013, by digit tabulation range (ZCTA), for the State of Iowa. First, we would like to point out that many digits have mortality rates at or above 30%, which shows the importance of assessing patients "survival prospects at the time of diagnosis to make accurate treatment decisions.

sections.heading: II. LEARNING GEOGRAPHICAL REPRESENTATIONS FOR SURVIVAL CURVE PREDICTION
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss our methodology, first outlining some preliminary notation and problem facets, followed by a discussion of Kaplan-Meier's re-presentation. Next, we will discuss the problem of predicting individual Kaplan-Meier curves and formalize the notion of making such predictions using neural networks. Finally, we will discuss the various geographical representations examined in this paper.

sections.heading: B. Kaplan-Meier Re-representation
sections.text: With our preliminary notation we return to the elaboration of the censored nature of the data. However, as already mentioned, each instance i has a corresponding event label e (i) and the time of the event t (i). However, we would like to transform this tubular representation into one in the form of a Kaplan Meier Survival Curve (KMSC) [3]. Simply put, a KMSC associates each temporal unit - in this case the values 1,.., T - with a probability of the event e (i) that does not occur until that particular time, for example. Practically speaking, this representation will take the form of a vector y (i), where the indices t (1,...., T) include the temporal units and the inputs y (i) t (i) t (t) t of the corresponding probabilities. sections.heading: C. Predicting Individual KMSC
sections.text: The ultimate goal of this paper is to learn a hypothesis that belongs to some (currently) arbitrarily defined class G hypotheses that most accurately predicts patient-specific RMSCs. Formally, however, this problem can be written as if it is an arbitrary loss function that measures the inequality between the predicted y (i) (i), g (x (i)) and the known y (i). In this paper, we define our class G hypotheses as both flat and deep neural networks, the specific architecture of which is further elaborated in this section, with parameterization discussed in the experimental section.

sections.heading: D. Geographic Feature Representation
sections.text: While we are ultimately interested in producing a g that produces the most accurate predictions, the niche of this work is to: 1) Show whether geographic characteristics improve the quality of predictions. 2) Determine whether a simple binary representation or a richer representation (defined shortly) leads to better predictions. 3) Experimentally, we quantify the extent of such improvements. 1) Simple graphical representation of our experiments and data in the next section, where two geographical representations are examined: a simple binary representation (SBR) and a richer representation produced via spectral analysis (RR-SA). 1) Simple graphical representation: The simple binary representation (SBR) is a minimalist representation that contains only (one) determination of the instance of i's discrete geographical entity and (b) a binary re-representation of such representation (other than a hot encoding) that we generate.

sections.heading: III. PREDICTING COLORECTAL CANCER SURVIVAL
sections.text: In this section, we begin with a detailed description of the data used in our experiments, followed by a sketch of the technical details of our experiments. Then, in our experiments, we discuss xz (i) latitude and longitude coordinates. Let us compare experiments and results by comparing the average predicted survival curve with the average actual survival curve model-wise, as well as the absolute error from model to model when the smoothing process is removed.

sections.heading: A. Colorectal Cancer Survival Data for the State of Iowa
sections.text: Our data was provided by the Iowa Cancer Registry (ICR), the State Health Registry of Iowa (SHRI) and the Iowa Department of Public Health (IDPH). Each case represents a patient diagnosed with colorectal cancer who is resident in the State of Iowa at the time of diagnosis. The data set consists of n = 46116 patients and initially m = 71 characteristics. After removing identifiers and features that exhibit a large number of cases with missing values (% missing > 50%), we were left with m = 26 unique characteristics (including unprocessed geographic coordinates) and m = 386 (without geographic characteristics) after binding discrete characteristics. By using geographic rerepresentation of SBR, m = 1364 (386 non-geographic characteristics and p = 978 binary geographic characteristics) and m = 386 + k when using the geographic characteristics of tumors (where parameterized and therefore a tumor is usable).

sections.heading: IV. RELATED WORK
sections.text: The topics related to disease prediction that are discussed during this work can best be categorized as disease and survival curve prediction and geographical prediction and representation, and there are many previous papers on disease prediction that can be considered classification-based [6] - [12] and survival-based [4], [10], [13] that have historically been used to make such predictions, decision trees [14] and neural network models [4], [15], [16] which are recent developments. However, Laurentiis and Ravdin [17] point out that CPH has several caveats compared to neural network-based approaches.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we investigated the use of two distinct geographical characteristics - a simple binary representation (SBR) and a rich representation based on spectral clustering (which we call spectral analysis and methodically call RR-SA) - to predict patient survival curves in the US state of Iowa. We show that (a) survival curves can be reasonably estimated, although predictive performance varies near the five-year survival mark, (b) the use of geographical characteristics generally leads to better predictions, and (c) RR-SA-trained models are better than those trained with SBR. Future work will include exploring various geographical representations, particularly those learned in conjunction with g-SA. Further research should also be undertaken into areas and scenarios where geographical representations of SBR and RR-SA provide benefits.

sections.heading: VI. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: The authors thank the Iowa Cancer Registry, the State Health Registry of Iowa and the Iowa Department of Public Health for the data, Gary Hulett and Jason Brubaker for their help in building the records, and Prakash Nadkarni for his help in data collection and the IRB process.

metadata.abstractText: Neural networks are capable of learning rich, nonlinear feature representations shown to be beneficial in many predictive tasks. In this work, we use these models to explore the use of geographical features in predicting colorectal cancer survival curves for patients in the state of Iowa, spanning the years 1989 to 2012. Specifically, we compare model performance using a newly defined metric – area between the curves (ABC) – to assess (a) whether survival curves can be reasonably predicted for colorectal cancer patients in the state of Iowa, (b) whether geographical features improve predictive performance, and (c) whether a simple binary representation or richer, spectral clustering-based representation perform better. Our findings suggest that survival curves can be reasonably estimated on average, with predictive performance deviating at the five-year survival mark. We also find that geographical features improve predictive performance, and that the best performance is obtained using richer, spectral analysis-elicited features.
